commentBody: Happy Monday, True Believers.
Maybe it’s just the weekend catching up to me, but this felt a little trickier than a typical Monday. Fun puzzle but not quite the usual quick easy solve
I appreciate Sam pointing out the good and the bad. I agree that UPC was cleverly clued and that ANAG should never appear in a crossword.

I agree a little crunchy for a Monday: spotlighting ANGI and ANAG. However the crosses helped. 1:38 under my average for a Monday. I tend to disagree with Otra for Spanish for other. I’ve only ever seen it as otro. Interesting puzzle though

ARIL? 
ANGI?

I’m not a fan, too obscure, especially on a Monday. (Not to mention AARONJUDGE (who he?) lying across ROGER ( who he?))

"I love aerial photos!"
"Yeah, you drone on about them."

("Don't you want to hear more?"
"You can film me in later.")
A secret theme, I like it

After 2 mins:  "This is easy, this is easy"
After 15 mins: "Why you hate me so much?" :)
Had to brute force Angi and Lanai. Not a fan of this one for a Monday.
Aye, Captain
Subtle is certainly the word for the theme, really really subtle.
I look forward to Mondays because they’re easy and fun, this one was neither.

Super easy, typical Monday. There were no 35A's for me.

Didn't even notice the theme though. I think maybe it was a bit too subtle.

Can’t say I struggled too much with this one (6:13 to solve) but it did feel both crunchier and sweatier than your typical Monday. The vowel run helps explain the combo, though add me to the list of solvers who didn’t notice it until I read this column afterwards.
aye aye captain
I enjoyed this and liked that it was a bit more than the regular Monday.
Shoutout to Helen Wright at 30D!
For those of you who are unaware (and I am guessing that includes many of you), today's puzzle is by the editor of the LA Times crossword.
Aril enjoyable Monday puzzle.

One aspect of the solve that I really enjoy is when I get to learn a new word as a bonus!

I’m not sure when I will use it in conversation, but I love now knowing ELIDE. 

Thank you!

I thought 24D was utterly preposterous, completely wrong, totally off-base.

Barry, tell me how wrong I am.

Please?

Enjoyed this. The theme was so subtle I missed it. Still enjoyable. I am amazed, every day, that someone has been able to put a puzzle together where there are words that cross other words and they all fit! Not something I could do. Thank you!

Just to explain about ANGI—that is a shortened version of the original site, which was ANGIe's List, a place to find people who could do a variety of home upkeep and repairs; and was national in scope and local in specifics; different service providers depending on the local area. There are a couple of similar websites out there.

Am not supposed to be walking very much until my feet are in better shape shape, so I did the puzzle on the iPad, and managed to beat my average, barely, which is unusual because I'm almost always over my average when I do that. No difficulties encountered, but really did it more as a themeless, and discovered the theme from the column.

We are honored to have a nice Monday from some of the NYT's competition, and it's nice to see another Patty Varol puzzle anytime. Thanks!

This is by far the hardest Monday puzzle I've ever seen.  Five or six clues that are from super obscure spheres of knowledge.  ELIDE?  ANGI?   What the hell is a LULU and who knows the acronym UPC?

Way too many obscure acronyms, this is like a Wednesday,

For the Monday of TW : 6.10 min

5982 puzzles solved
100 solve rate
746 current streak
746 best streak

Guess this was in my wheelhouse. Smooth solve, but I was surprised to finish and find my time was over 2 minutes faster than my Monday average. 

I did get and enjoy the theme, but not until I  got to AO.

The theme went over my head, like a drone taking an aerial photo of a herd of puzzle-solvers in the outback scratching their heads in puzzlement while the hungry emus stalk ever closer to them. 

How many of you discovered the theme while you were doing this one? I want to hear some bragging!

Quiz:

you all know that these two words have their vowels in order: abstemious and facetious (and can even include "y" if you wish, in their adverbial form). What are the one or two other words that contain the vowels in order? No cheating! If you know you know.

Quiz #2:

What (few) words have their vowels in backwards order (beginning with "u" that is)? 

I liked this one's push-back. Like a Monday cookie with some Wednesday walnuts. A Monday puzzle for grownups. 

Answers:

Anemious – relating to or affected by wind, rarely used.
Arsenious – relating to arsenic.
I'd also accept Adventitious.
There's a few others but no one ever uses them.

Second quiz:

Fooled yah: there's only one word:
unnoticeable
A baseball slugger intersecting with another baseball slugger? Really?
Just made my longest streak of a lowly 29.

To top off Sunday's love letter to Star Trek TOS, tonight we watched season three, episode 4 of Strange New Worlds and it's another beautiful love letter!! 

Especially loved Uhura's, as her holideck character, speech of the importance and wonder of sci-fi and the trailblazing nature of TOS.

Be still my nerdy little heart!!

🖖

Re 3D: FRIARs, or Friars Mendicant, are not monks, and in general live in the community, nor in monasteries.

L
Today’s theme reminded me of themes from days gone past that were more about words and their structure and less about puns and cutesy wordplay.
ANGI not ANGIe, AUDRE not AUDREy. Who knew? Proper names are my  nemesis. 😉

Crunchy Monday and I had to hunt down a 
typo. Had AMa instead of AMO. I can’t even blame it on a fat finger since A is nowhere near O 🤷🏼‍♀️ Not GONNA lie, I completely missed the theme 😬 It just flew right over me. I searched and searched and just couldn’t see it. Oh well, still enjoyed the solve ☺️ Thank you, Patti!!

I struggled a bit on this one, 2:xx slower than my average. 

Theme went right over my head—when I saw the section of the column regarding the theme…just, what?

Makes me a little concerned for my -actual- Monday tomorrow. Would prefer a less Monday-y Monday.

ANGI for Angie is right in vogue now.  Pants are now pant, canned food is now can food, frying pans are now fry pans. These are just a few of a zillion examples of lopping off a letter or two, and for what?  Does it actually save enough space to save on paper, lower advertising costs, or have any benefit to anyone?  The NY Times and The New Yorker are both doing it now.
Is today Wednesday? It sure seems like it......

I found this a little bit more difficult than the typical Monday, but that’s ok. I like that.

ANAG is new to me, but fortunately I didn’t have to deal with it. It filled in through the crosses. As for ANGI… that’s the evil stepchild of Angie’s List. Or, the sold-to-the-highest-bidder website that emerged from the ashes of the neighbor-reviewed, non-ad influenced local services directory that failed to make a profit. 

I may be a little bitter because I once had this great idea for a website where people could find great contractors (or avoid bad ones) by reading about other people’s experiences… only to find out someone else had just started one, and her name was Angie. I’m also sad because I relied on that site, a lot, and it’s gone. The new version is just paid promotions. And now I’m back to finding people through Facebook. 

Anyone know a good handyman who does fascia and siding repairs? I’m in the market.
For an 11-Letter AY entry: AYESHA CURRY (restauranteur and Steph's wife)

Shout out to Roosevelt Island in the xword! I lived there for a few years a very long time ago. It was delightful. I had a panoramic water view and it felt secluded and quiet, even though I technically lived in Manhattan and had a 212 area code. When I was looking for apartments at age 21 it was much more affordable than Manhattan proper (although a bit harder to have a social life). My neighbors included a lot of UN personnel wearing interesting clothes from their native lands. 

For non new Yorkers, Roosevelt Island is located in the East River between Manhattan and Queens. It's accessible via the subway but also via a cool aerial TRAM that goes over the river at 59th Street. Oh and there's a bridge from Queens but no automobile traffic on the island. When I lived there the southern tip was off limits (of course we explored it) and contained the ruins of a 19th century asylum of some kind. I believe it's now a park and residences. I'd be interested to hear what it's like today.
Tough for a Monday. Too many US specific clues for a Brit today. No matter I’ll be back for more tomorrow
Delulu I never heard of.   Angi's fka Angie's List I definitely have heard of, and used once.
I was clearly not the target audience for this crossword. Coming from both a geographic and demographic disadvantage this was quite a slog. Nevertheless I persist!

How I was able to complete this, and in good time, and without lookups, too, I will never understand - for me there were more unknown names and items of trivia than in many a late-week puzzle. Of course I never noticed there was a theme, either. I've learned of AEIOU from these puzzles - I still remember how stumped I was when I encountered that mysterious sequence of letters in a past puzzle. Still, to notice the thing was an undercurrent in today's puzzle was beyond me.

Essentially, this solved like a themeless, trivia-heavy grid - not my favorite kind. The solve may have been quick but it provided no enjoyment for me. Bummer.

The only semi-interesting thing about Poland the grid inspired me to say has to do with ROTC. We have nothing of the sort over here, possibly for historical reasons. "Studium wojskowe" ("Military course") was an obligatory month spent by male students on army training under "communism." (Men who did not go to university spent a year or two in the army). Most people in the studium wojskowe, like my dad, ended up with the infantry, and some with artillery, like my father in law. Of course they learned very little. My dad mostly remembers the rock-hard, salted herring they were served at the cantina. The concept of studium wojskowe, like almost everything else tied to the old, pre-1989 regime, was phased out under democracy, and it's unlikely to ever return by association to "communism."

Crossing of LANAI and ANGI meant I had to hit check puzzle or double my time, already a bit tardy for a Monday. Couldn’t flyspeck as I just couldn’t see MILLIONTHS as anything but MILLI ONTHS, and thought it was wrong. Happens sometimes.

Note to self: memorise ANA de Armas. Or actually watch a film made after 1983.

No one seems to have commented on 27A. It hasn’t been clued this way in a while, but it’s wrong. Ore has to be smelted to yield metal. (The metal atoms are bound up in compounds, generally oxides of some sort, and need to be reduced to their metallic form.)

That was one of the least enjoyable crosswords I've seen for a long time: ANGI? ANAG? LANAI? RAID? And that was just the SE corner.

Is TACH really a thing? And UPC? And AARON JUDGE crossed with ROGER. I mean, c'mon.

If I hadn't seen ANGI in the column, I wouldn't have made it
This was the Fridayest Monday I have ever Mondayed.

Why is the fill for 8D’s clue:
   “Musician Brian who has an asteroid named after him”
Not “MAY” instead of ENO, other than that it wouldn’t fit the crosses?

AYCARAMBA
AYESHACURRY
AYEAYECAPTAIN

An enjoyable Monday puzzle. Southwest corner was just a bit tough but managed to work it out. And... a nice moment when I was almost done and pondered for a moment and finally caught on to the theme. Surprised at the complaints, but...whatever. And.. puzzle find today: A Tuesday from November 16, 2004 by Stella Daily and Bruce Venzke. Don't recall seeing another one quite like this. Four theme answers, and all of them had the same clue: "Uh-uh!" Those answers: YOUMUSTBEJOKING WHENPIGSFLY THERESNOWAY AINTGONNAHAPPEN Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/16/2004&g=59&d=A I'm done. ....
The solution to the clue describing the "path of a baseball popup" is, in fact, true for any baseball hit.  ANY hit.  Jus' sayin'...

If you pronounce it correctly, ANAG is a thing you can scramble.
Close enough for NYT XWDS.

AYCARUMBAs is probably not a standard pluralization.
Had my 53A replaced 4 years ago so every puzzle is a blessing.    Thought we had a themeless going at first but soon caught on.  Nice one and thanks.
What a refreshing,  welcome change! No complaints of a puzzle too easy! Oh frabjous day!

Did I spot the "vowel progression"?  No.
Do I care that I did not spot it?  Of course not.  
I haven't even had a whole cup of coffee (black, half-caf.)  

Nice Lil Monday Puzz.
Personal connection to the puzzle's content:
PhysicsDaughter was born in 1980 with an AORTIC defect (which was bad luck) but was resuscitated by a NICU team from Children's Hospital of Cincinnati (which was very good luck.)  Welcome to Parenthood!  
Would you believe we went on to have a little brother for the complete set?!
He doesn't do xwords any more, and she only does crosswords when she's here visiting or recuperating from something; oh well.  I tried.  Someone else will have to supply the Next Generation of solvers!

Not a fan of HAZE; this is the first day I've been able to open my windows in more than a week. It's been heat, then smoke, then heat, then smoke, and I'm about ready to lose my mind.

Still, this was a fun Monday puzzle. If I were in a worse mood, I might be upset about the crossing of two Baseball People in the NE, but the smoke is mostly gone and I'm feeling charitable. At least I got an OREO out of it.

I also did not get the vowel progression....nevertheless there were some interesting clues/answers, UPC and ELIDE (new to me). The old Met's Shea station in Flushing Queens, brought back wonderful memories of time I spent with my grandparent's at their home, just off Union Turnpike near St John's University.

Another Monday I take issues with.  Too many overly specific clues tied together.  To me these types feel less in the spirit of gamesmenship and fairness.  Less solvable imo then any of last week's puzzles

Words I mostly know from Spelling Bee: ARIL, LANAI, LULU (which I do hear in normal context but pretty rarely)

Had OTRo before OTRA -- I usually leave the last letter blank but somehow didn't this time. Oops. 

Any complaints this time about product placement for OREO? Hope not. That was pretty silly.

Roger Maris was very kind to me when at age 12 I rushed across the street for an autograph. He ruffled my hair and it stayed unwashed for two weeks. My parents had to drag me to the sink. He did a tour at the Big Bear Grocery store. One of best days of my life.

[Roddenberry and namesakes] would have been a fun clue for GENES.

Levy, Kelly, Wilder and Hackman are all good Genes.



Sorry.

Difficult but not for fun reasons.  

So much crossing of niche names and words, and specific trivia, in relatively closed corners.  

Didn't leave any fun to solve my way around it, just slog and lookup.  

And there has to he another way to hint Adele at this point I swear that skyfall clue makes a weekly appearance.

Quick question for the experienced NYT crossword folks.  I've been having this issue lately where I complete the crossword correctly, but then it doesn't show that.  I get the almost there pop-up message.  After an exasperating review, I go to the answer key and my filled puzzle matches exactly.  This has happened twice in the past week.  What am I doing wrong?
Can someone explain HIE?
In the spirit of if you don’t have anything nice to say don’t say anything at all, I’ll just say that this puzzle does not meet the editorial standards of the NYT.

Interesting how the column is divided between people who found it easy (mostly American citizens) and those who found it difficult or unpleasant (mostly not Americans). I don't think I would have the ability to even attempt a puzzle in another language, let alone another culture. My hat is off to those of you who regularly do the NYT puzzle, and do it well. Yes, some of our cultural (many, I should say) clues are mysteries to you, but you have certainly learned quite a few of them as you have done more and more of these puzzles. You are challenging your brain, which is excellent, btw, for your brain health, and adding to our knowledge when you supply us with comparable information from your own culture. 

Thank you for sharing your own thoughts and experiences here; the conversation is every bit as uplifting as the puzzle.

AYO EDEBIRI for a 10-letter extender of the theme. 

I did object to the sports slugger Natick, but the crosses were gentle enough that I could avoid lookups. And it was weirdly nice to see ACTV for once, instead of the endless ACTI and ACTII entries.

This was one of my faster solves, despite having several names I've never heard of  (thank you crosses!)

After I finished, I looked back for the theme I had missed. Other than noticing that the longer answers all started with "A", I had nothing. 

Thank goodness the wordplay column filled me in, or I would never have gotten it.  😄

Not one of my favorites, but as a dyed in the wool Yankees fan, the crossing of the two N.Y. sluggers was heart warming.  Sadly, when Maris bested Babe Ruth’s home run record in 1961 he had to put up with much derogatory press and undue pressure, causing this pleasant, honest man to actually begin losing his hair.  He was a gentleman, but a person not suited for the press coverage in NYC.  It is also fitting that Judge bested the 61 home run record set by Maris, a fellow Yankee.
I thought the main heroine in Star Wars was Leia not Rey. What gives here?

I didn’t find this difficult, but I do think the clues are pretty niche and clunky for a Monday. I don’t mind this so much later in the week in the service of a great theme (lord knows I’m guilty of it in my own puzzles) but this didn’t seem to merit it. I do think ANGI is fair, Angie’s List was pretty popular, kind of like Craig’s List, although not everyone may know about the name change
And here I was thinking it was a fun, easy Monday solve.  Apparently I am in the minority, judging by the comments.  I think I'll go play some Strauss and dance.

I really enjoyed this puzzle. Zero lookups, a little crunchy, but I was on the same wavelength with this crossword constructor. Being a baseball researcher is so fun when it actually helps my solving, but given that I'm a Negro Leagues scholar, the clues are rarely within my wheelhouse; today I happened to know the multiple specific clues. That being said, ARC was my last to fill in, and I agree with others that I didn't love that clueing. 

I'd definitely recommend the movie 61* to watch to learn more about the Maris v Mantle home run race. Billy Crystal directed and co-produced it as a love letter to NY baseball, even though Tigers Stadium was used as the filming location for Yankee Stadium. As a Tigers fan, I love that detail :-)

Love the apt crossing of AARONJUDGE and ROGER (Maris).  I met Patti at ACPT earlier this year and learned she's a baseball fan (see her April bonus puzzle).

10- or 13-letter entries for 'AY': AYECAPTAIN or AYEAYECAPTAIN.
Very well done but hard for a Monday puzzle in my opinion.

Patti Varol is a good puzzle editor. Glad to see her get one of her own published here. 

Her LAT edited puzzles are run by the Wash Post. A few weeks ago, the Post reformatted their online puzzles into an awful neon color chiclet tile design with each puzzle load preceded by a mandatory ad. As a longtime Post subber, I refused to even view those puzzles and sent the department comments about it. 

The Post has now made the online puzzles more palatable, so I'm glad to say that Patti's edited grids are back in my daily life.

The theme would have worked better had there not been so many other across words beginning with A in the puzzle. This filled like a themeless for me, I had to come to the article to find out what it was in the end. Unsatisfying solve for me.
It’s amazing how one word can ruin it for you. ANAG was that word. AINTGONNAHAPPEN

I always consider Monday crosswords an introduction to new puzzlers...a way to get them interested amd give them some early successes. Sadly, this was no such Monday. Wonderful for a Tuesday...but so many not-so-readily recognizable names, places, etc. But that is just my view of things. A very good puzzle, Patti...but perhaps, editor(s), best for a later day....

This felt a tad mean for a Monday. Way too many obscure/unknowns for some of us beyond your shores. Not the constructors fault, I don’t think they get a say on which day their work will run. 
I don’t like complaining, so instead I’ll go with Yay, for 30D. My girls say thank you. I’m trying to clean their fleeces to salvage enough to spin. It’s not looking good (long hot summer does not a good fleece make).

One more late puzzle find. I don't recall ever seeing another one quite like this. Anyway... a Sunday from March 26, 1995 by Rich Norris with the title "Positive thinking." Some clue and answer examples: "One with no work grievances" GRUNTLEDEMPLOYEE "Reliable hearsay" FOUNDEDRUMOR "Unpredictable outcome" EVITABLERESULT "Good manners" RULYBEHAVIOR "It's easily erased" DELIBLEINK And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/26/1995&g=54&d=A ...
"Anyone mind if this white boy speaks a little español this evening?"

You know what drives me crazy? When people ELIDE the first T in "important." I'm not sure why, but it strikes me as deliberate abuse of the English language. There's a life insurance commercial running where the spokesperson does that. At least she says "insurance" correctly, by not accentuating the first syllable. That also grinds my gears.

Maybe it's because I'm from Boston, but I have no issues whatsoever with dropping the R.
This is a great puzzle, but it is not a great Monday puzzle. It would feel more fitting for a Tuesday or a Wednesday.

I couldn't remember whether the Spanish for "other" was OTRA or OTRO and I didn't want to look it up, so I just guessed. Then, once I filled in the whole grid and it was saying I had an error, I had to go through every answer twice before I noticed I had accidentally written AIN'T GONNo HAPPEN in 39 across. So that was kind of annoying. Otherwize, a pretty eazy puzzle.
just an absolute train wreck of proper nouns crossing each other all over the map. this was awful.

I forgot to start my week with Autocheck and that plus me being so tired that I had entered "ELuDE" for 57D, one of the last items to check when I had to find at least one error, made this puzzle cost me an eternal 18:07. Ridiculous!

Wow, that took WAY longer than a normal Monday. Mainly because I apparently don't know how to spell the name of the Star Wars heroine. Rae? REa? Oh, REY! My New Hope is that I will remember that spelling for the next time it comes along!

I'm so sick of "____: abbr." as a clue for words that have no standard abbreviations. Yes, typically in lazy fashion, the answer will just be the first however many letters of the "true" answer, but this is not always the case and is certainly not always the case for real-life abbreviated words! How am I to decide which letters the puzzle creator arbitrarily included in the made-up abbreviation? The truth is that this is a cop-out clue to force something that isn't a word to become a word, and I'd prefer some more transparency there, or at least a cuter clue. For example "ANAG" could've been something like "someone who is always getting on your case" as in "quit being such a nag." Is it the strongest clue? No, definitely not, but it's so much more transparent in its weakness than just pretending that anyone in their right mind would think "anag" was short for anagram.

Too easy and much too full of crosswordese to be much fun, except for the fact that there was a time - a long, long time ago - when I might have welcomed a return to the old groaners like "aril" or "Agra" or even "lulu". (What? Missed the chance to clue "etui"?) But no longer.

That said, there's a rather unsettling clash between the tired traditional answers throughout most of the puzzle and the answer to 39A. Phew! Where did that come from?

At first I thought that maybe I had somehow stubbled upon an easy-clue version of the puzzle, because this was so elementary, even for a Monday. But I guess not.

I have to give a lot of credit to crossword puzzle constructors for undertaking such a daunting task, but let's face it:  As in all of life's endeavors, some attempts are more successful than others. This one was just not that good.

I don't see a wordplay article for the August bonus crossword puzzle, so I'm putting this comment here--I just completed the August bonus puzzle and found an error. I emailed the NYT games about it but thought I'd put in here in case that email isn't checked. For 65A the clue is: "If I loved you less, I might be able to talk about it more" speaker in a Jane Austen novel. However, the speaker that fits in that space is not the correct speaker. Mr. Knightley spoke that line, not Emma. As a big Austen fan, I spotted this right away and was very surprised!
I have learned quite a lot of Star Trek, Star Wars, baseball, and rapper names while beginning to forget more useful info like Guana? Gyana?… No, Ghana.

What is it about the puzzle lately that has me thinking about 20th c. Viennese expressionist opera? Here's a little song, full of SHARPS and flats, the gist of which is: "you think I will ever be that nice, respectable girl, with the kind of safe tonal center you can take home to Mother? AINT GONNA HAPPEN!: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CZzT8e8PeqY&list=RDCZzT8e8PeqY&start_radio=1
Of course “Derek Jeter” has the exact same amount of letters as “Aaron Judge”

Not a fan of this one - certainly not a Monday level crossword! I had to check a few times I was on the right day!
Usually the niche American culture references dont fox me too much but this one had way too many that us non-americans would just never be able to guess. Abit disappointed....

God i was awful today. Usually i've been doing well on mondays but today was hard for me. A lot of baseball references i don't get because i'm brazilian and a lot of specific things a person that's not from the U.S probably wouldn't get, but it's okay. New things to learn!
Just FYI - alpacas don’t produce wool, they produce fiber.
Not a fan of this one at all, definitely not a monday-level puzzle and I really didn't enjoy a lot of the clues (ANAG & ANGI were both extremely frustrating)
Grrrrrrr. Took me 10 minutes to find my AMpM/pRIAR mistake!
Weird one for a Monday, not gonna lie
I had no idea there was a theme other than words beginning with the letter A because, right off the bat, I misspelled AERIAL. Oh, well.

Sorry, but this was a big thumbs down for me, for a Monday puzzle. I can manage one or two sports references, but this is far too much baseball. And two of them cross? C'mon. I've never, ever heard of Aaron Judge or Roger Maris (Maris Roger?) so the G was a guess. 

Also, I'm happy to learn new words like LANAI, but when it crosses with another super obscure reference like ANGI (I'm American but haven't resided in the US for many years), I ended up doing something I've never done on a Monday: I went through the alphabet and tried every letter in that square until the puzzle was solved. Took the fun right out, I'm afraid. I call foul.

Welcome to the NYT Crosswords forum.

On Mondays we debate whether or not the puzzle was too hard (i.e. should have been a Friday).

The rest of the week we debate whether or not the puzzle was too easy (i.e. should have been a Monday).

I guess I’m in the minority, this was delicious and I finished 2 min faster than my average! 

Anytime I see Lorde mentioned, I think of that absolutely unhinged PowerPoint linking her to trump getting elected. Anyone else? No? I’ll see myself out ✌️

An interesting Monday. We found it atypical, but enjoyable. My wife learned that I took a Latin class when I was in middle school. 
My feminist theory background was called upon with Audre Lorde. Unfortunately we only got it because of the crosses, not because I could put her name with her work.
too much baseball but otherwise ok.

This was definitely not what I was bracing for on a Monday. I won’t fault the crossword itself: there were some good clues (I enjoyed “short lines at the register” a lot, and for a change I actually learned something about Eno), and of course the whole thing was well and doable, but this was a tricky Wednesday or a breezy Friday, not a Monday. 

I will say, though, as someone who otherwise enjoys the sport: I would be very, very happy if we outlawed baseball crosses permanently, irrevocably, and with extreme prejudice (like 11A and 18D here). This includes player names and stat initialisms.

this puzzle had a bunch of big smiles for me. i am not at all a yankees fan, but i am a new yorker who loves baseball--so having AARONJUDGE, ROGER maris, and my beloved SHEA all in one puzzle was a real treat! and AUDRELORDE too? just wow.

and i know this has been said a million times before, but complaining about unfamiliar topics (like baseball or queer poets) is not a good look. just take it as an opportunity to learn something new. geez.
3D: Google says FRIARS actually live among the general public… the monks live in the monastery.

Was anyone else troubled by 11 Down “Emphatic Rejection”?  The answer was GODNO.  While I occasionally use that phrase myself, I feel it is disrespectful to the God in which I believe.  (Never mind a violation of the 2nd commandment.)  
This is not the first time I have been surprised/shocked to see a popular word/phrase in the puzzle and feared that its appearance in the NYT crossword would further legitimize it.  I wish the editors would be more sensitive to that.
@Mike Definitely a crunchy Monday.

@Mike
I had one cheat (which I never need on a Monday puzzle). I'd never heard of 'angi' and couldn't think of what followed 'prayer', "prayer vi_il".   Prayer vigil!  I remember those, now....

@Joan

ANGI is what they now call what used to be Angie's List.

@Mike
Several have said this was harder.  It was easier for me.  I sailed through in 2/3 usual Monday time. 
Maybe it's because I knew ANGI and ROGER Maris?

I think it's because I've told my kids, AINT GONNA HAPPEN too many times.
@Eric maybe ANAG in reference to a horse... No, not that, either.
@Megan Otto for a masculine object and otra for feminine. The better clues hint at which gender. Otherwise you have to check the cross.
@Petrol AARONJUDGE and ROGER Maris are both legendary New York Yankees.  New York, New York!

@Petrol

Permit me to introduce you to my childhood hero, the late, great Roger Maris.

Roger Maris was a quiet, shy kid from North Dakota and northern Minnesota.  He was an astonishing ball player--power hitter, and less known for his rocket arm from right field.

He only played for the Yankees a few years, once of which he topped Babe Ruth's season home run total of 60, although Maris played 162 games in that season, but Ruth only 154.  He failed to hit 61 home runs in his first 154 games.

He was widely hated in New York, because he was not press savvy like Mickey Mantle, Yogi Berra, Whitey Ford, and others of the Yankees from that era.  The press thought he was surly, and to an extent he was.  But it was mostly misunderstanding.

His story is brilliantly told in the HBO movie 61*.  

He died very young, 51, from non-Hodgkin lymphoma.  Thankfully, Yankee fans accepted him as time went on.

And yet, he's *not*, I repeat NOT, in the Baseball Hall of Fame.  He had a single season home run record that stood for 37 years.  Before the steroid era.  This is, in my opinion, the second most embarrassing omission in Major League baseball, right after ignoring the Negro leagues for decades, even though the Negro Leagues were every bit as good as the Major Leagues.

I saw him once at an old-timers exhibition game at an All-Star Game in the early 80s.  He must have been diagnosed about that time.

Sorry, I get a little nostalgic, a little verbose when it comes to my guy, Roger Maris.

@Francis Thank you for writing this. It reminded me of the 1963 Yankees-Dodgers World Series that broke my heart. I was New York born, but living in Glendale, California at the time and in 5th grade. @Francis,

The Game of the Week was on CBS, and for a while they had part ownership of the Yankees. So the GOTW was always a Yankees game for a while. 

Which was fine by me. I grew up in southwest Missouri, just outside of Joplin, where Mantle played a year of minor league ball for the Joplin Miners.  One of my uncles would go to see him play there and hit tape-measure home runs. He had seen him do the same in nearby Baxter Springs, Kansas, once passing the hat in the stands to buy a new ball to replace the one that Mantle hit about 500 feet into Center Creek. 

I became a Yankees fan in 1961, when Mantle and Maris were have their “home run race” to see who could break Babe Ruth’s record of 60 HR.  What an exciting time that was! 

Maris had so much to deal with regarding the New York press. I remember the local TV station breaking into regular programming with the news that he had broken Ruth’s record in the final day of the season.

I've been fascinated by Roosevelt Island since I saw the movie "Dark Water" with Jennifer Connelly.  

I'd been to New York City a few times by then, but was still surprised by the island's existence.

It'll definitely be on my to-do list if I ever get back to New York.

@Francis

Roosevelt Island is about 2 miles long, with the southernmost .3 mi. consisting of parkland.  In this area are located the preserved ruins of the smallpox hospital, and at the southern tip of the island, the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Four Freedoms Park.  These two sites are interesting to see, and of course, there are breathtaking views of Manhattan.

To the north of that area is Cornell's tech campus.  Then comes a sports complex featuring, among other things, an indoor pool.  Then you pass under the Ed Koch Queensboro Bridge.  Beyond that are mostly non-descript high-rise apartment buildings.  Of course, not being Manhattan Island (although technically still Manhattan), you can pick up lunch at a local eatery or supermarket for less than you would on the bigger island to the west.  Near the northern tip, there's a large nursing home complex, and then another park, this one honoring journalist and women's rights activist Nellie Bly. 

A back-and-forth walk the length of the island from either the tram or the subway (I'd recommend the tram) should take about two hours, and is an interesting counterpoint to the bustle of Manhattan.

@Francis

The regime was just an oligarchic dictatorship masquerading as communism - there was a ruling class (the "Worker's" Party) who owned the state and its means of production, and distributed wealth however they saw fit. Granted, Polish society between 1945 and 1989 was much more egalitarian than under capitalism, but there still were the haves and have-nots, and the powerful (the clique of party big wigs) and the powerless (everybody else). It was a parody of Marx's communist ideals. Communism is about a society without states and social class, with the means of production owned communally, and wealth distributed equally between everybody.

@Søren Thustrup

TACH is short for tachometer, and is a common usage here in the USA. ANGI was originally called Angie's List.

@Søren Thustrup
Agreed - after last week's stellar puzzles this really felt like a step down!

@Søren Thustrup
No offense to foreign solvers but I never understood why they complain about Americanism's in a crossword produced by an American entity for an American audience. As an American, everyone one of your complaints was a gimme for me.

@Søren Thustrup

ANAG is an abbreviation that we do not commonly see in everyday use; one commenter pointed out that it's frequently used in (British-style) cryptic puzzles, but I've never seen it (although I admit to having done very few of those).  This might be the only answer that's a little dubious from a US point of view.

You might get a pass on ANGI, as that is a US-based app for finding tradespeople for your household repairs, and UPC (Universal Product Code), the bar codes found on practically everything, might be an unfamiliar abbreviation in Copenhagen (although I'll bet you have them).

AARON JUDGE and ROGER Maris are famous baseball players, the former current, the latter from the 60s, so as a non-US citizen, those may be hard for you.  I still don't understand how baseball has caught on in Latin America and the Far East, but Europe remains averse to the sport.

RAID is a major bug spray brand here.  LANAI is a Hawaiian word, but sometimes used on the mainland.  

And TACH is definitely a thing.

Hope this helps!

@ChatGPT-1

A negative personal review is not a complaint - it's just a truthful account of a solver's experience. I myself did not much like this puzzle. Am I complaining by saying that?

@Andrzej

It's the tone.

"Is TACH really a thing?"...of course it is.  Many cars have tachometers.

"And UPC?"  At least this maybe a typically US or English-language abbreviation, but I'm sure there are bar codes in Denmark, too.

You can't complain the puzzle's bad just because you don't know what things are called.

(I'd allow that Europeans wouldn't know who ROGER Maris was, and AARON JUDGE is, both gimmes for a NY baseball fan.)

@Steve L

You can dislike a puzzle, especially a Monday one, for featuring so many unknowns. And it's hard to post in a positive tone about a puzzle you didn't like. Requiring people who did not enjoy a grid to either keep quiet or be super nice about it seems perverse. Surely you see that?

@Steve L,

I have never, ever understood why car manufacturers insist on taking up so much dashboard real estate with a TACHometer. Has anyone outside of race car drivers ever cared how many RPMs their engines are revved up to? I would much rather have gauges for battery charge and water temperature like I had on my first car, a 1953 Chevy.

@Andrzej

C’mon. I’ve got to go with Steve and @ChatGPT-1 (not to be confused with going with ChatGPT) on this. It’s not disliking a given puzzle that’s the issue, it’s the implicit challenge in the rhetorical “Is TACH really a thing? And UPC?” You’re doing a puzzle in the New York Times. What would be your first guess? Those were gimme's, as were LANAI (really, you haven’t seen that one in puzzles lately??), ROGER Maris and AARON JUDGE, and, for that matter, RAID, ANGI, and ANAG. Guess why?

If I’m reading a novel by a British writer and come across a piece of dialogue such as, say, “Chance would be a fine thing,” I don’t complain to anyone within earshot, “oh come on, who says that? Is that really a thing?” I assume it’s a colloquialism used in the U.K., Google it, and learn something new.

If you’re not interested in coming across U.S. idioms, expressions, commercial products, and sports references with which you may not be familiar, why on earth do a U.S. Xword?
@Søren Thustrup yes, a UPC is definitely a thing in the US and Canada. In Europe the equivalent is an EAN or IAN.

@NYC Traveler
A tach is one of the most important things for a driver. @Jim
I had this trouble one day, but I have a quirk.  If I hold down the caps lock key my keyboard switches to Russian.  (I lived in St. Petersburg for 2 years recently.)  I accidentally did that, and typed the answer with Russian characters.  Oops -- I deleted the 3 squares that looked wrong, went back to English keyboard, and put in correct answer.

I finally had to do the correct puzzle feature.  I hadn't deleted the C in one square of my wrong word because it looked correct.  A C in Russian is the same place on the keyboard, and looks just like an English C.  But the underlying computer coding is different.  Every letter, number, character in almost every language has a different code, so the computer knows what to print.

I'm a coder from way back, so I knew exactly why it was wrong -- but it did blow my streak.

@Grant

Where I’m from, we tend to use a glottal stop for T’s in words like “important.” What gets on my nerves is that now people are trying to “correct” their accents, but still can’t really pronounce the T’s, so it comes out sounding like “impordun.” Really bugs me for some reason.
@Aubrey I agree. Maybe a Wednesday puzzle.

@Rob —it’s either! The usage depends on what’s being referred to, so we’re often in guessing mode (reliant on the crossing) for certain Spanish words. Each of (el, la, los, las) means “the”, (esto/este) mean “that”, and the list goes on. Happy crossing!
